prompt:
</s>County Court Judge Barbera Cottrell overturned earlier perjury convictions against Stephen Linnell, former media director of Victoria Police.
A Melbourne magistrate accepted
text:
the Crown's case that Linnell had lied to a magistrate in a bid to avoid a jail term.
But Judge Cottrell said the magistrate had failed to consider the "totality of the circumstances" and had not taken into account the "substantial" evidence Linnell had given in his defence.
Linnell, who was the media director for Victoria Police from 2002 to 2008, was convicted of perjury in 2010 after he was found to have lied to a magistrate about his involvement in a police raid on a Melbourne nightclub in 2008.
The raid was part of a police investigation into the alleged sexual assault of a woman at the nightclub.
Linnell was sentenced to three months in jail, but appealed the conviction.
In his appeal, Linnell argued the magistrate had failed to consider the "totality of the circumstances" and had not taken into account the "substantial" evidence he had given in his defence.
Judge Cottrell agreed with Linnell and overturned the convictions.
Linnell was not present in court for the decision.
He is due to be sentenced in the Victorian County Court on February 22.
- AAP

text:
the Reds, Anderson was the first African-American manager in the major leagues. He was also the first African-American manager in the American League.
Anderson was born in Birmingham, Ala., and played for the Tigers from 1955-1957. He was the manager of the Tigers from 1958-1960 and the Reds from 1961-1966.
He was inducted into the Baseball Hall of Fame in 1984.
Anderson was also a scout for the Tigers and the Reds.
He is survived by his wife, the former Mary Lou Johnson, and two sons, David and David Jr.
